transport.comment:
OP, you need to apply for the state tax credit and begin planning for a 2015 project (as the funds are fully reserved for 2014).

The most cost effective system will be one which costs the lesser of $30k or 14x your annual state income tax liability. 

At which point you will get roughly 65% of the system cost back on your taxes over the next 5 years. Turnkey solar costs in 2015 will likely be $3/W if you price it out, so at GA electricity prices you'll receive around a 5% return per year. 

So you'll be looking at a 7 year payback or so, sooner if you understand value the salvage/property value increase.

transport.comment:
>  what percentage would you suggest

Anywhere between 20 and 50% is sustainable, varying to the lower over time. Electricity supply in Canada is already ~60% renewable (hydro mostly) so once we move to electric cars then we're pretty much good to go.

> how to make the next generation of solar and wind capturing 
> devices and their auxiliary components

As long as the EROEI is > 1, who cares? It's still a net positive benefit. If you make PV from 100% coal power, you're still reducing between 5 and 10 times that amount of CO2 somewhere else. We're not installing PV on top of hydro and wind, we're installing it on top of coal and natgas. It's all good, and will just get better over time.

transport.comment:
I can't speak for folks "in general" but I can give you my statistics in hopes that it'll help you :-) . My house is completely electric (HVAC/HWH/etc) and on average about 1/3 of my usage goes to my car, 1/3 goes to my HVAC, and then then rest is "everything else". Specifics below:

I currently have a 19.52kW installation on my house in Maryland (so pretty close!). Roof is very suboptimal, EW orientation, with a little shading in the back. Last year I produced around 21 MWh.

I have a Tesla P85D, which I use to commute to work (20 miles each way), and drive pretty aggressively. Last year it consumed around 8 MWh.

I have a 3000 sqft house that is reasonably well insulated and kept at 69 degrees year long. It is heated/cooled by an electric GSHP (geothermal system). Last year it consumed around 9 MWh.

The rest of my home consumes somewhere in the range of 8MWh/year, so I'm currently a little shy on production (25 MWh consumed vs 21 MWh produced). Next month I'm having an additional 10.05 kW of panels installed on my roof. This will cover the 4 MWh I'm missing, plus give me some breathing roof for some installs down the road.

Let me know if you have other questions! All of this data was collected using Curb, which I highly recommend.

transport.comment: I recently spoke with a Tesla Model 3 owner, who is kind of obnoxious with his love of his car, but was actually outspokenly envious of our LEAF, because the only way he has one pedal is to use the screen to turn it on and off.  With the LEAF it is literally just a flick of the finger, so it can be used as an active part of normal driving, like stepping on the brake pedal.  The LEAF has always had a little bit of a video game feel to it. It can be very interactive if you want it to be. The regen "shifter" allows you 1) Coast/neutral 2) "D" drive with mild regen, "B" with stronger regen, and then the One Pedal switch for strong regen that literally brings you to a complete stop.  I very seldom touch the brake pedal.  This way we can both avoid using the friction brakes at all (except in emergencies when the car beeps at you then emergency stops itself, if you don't) and allows you to easily adjust your regen braking so that you can avoid over-charging beyond what the battery can take in at whatever its current level of charge is.  It makes driving a lot more interesting and actually fun.  We average 4.5miles/kWh (30-35% above spec economy and range) because of it, though we actually averaged 5.3 in our 2015 LEAF that had the same regen shifter but no One Pedal. I will definitely miss that aspect of driving a LEAF when we eventually move on to an electric van (Canoo hopefully)

transport.comment:
Your best bet is to use a hybrid ICE car.

That's amusing. Here, it's the opposite at the moment: gas being unstable and electricity being stable.

The other issue you may run into is certain towns or cities may not have many fast charging. Then, you have to plan how you travel based on that one charger that may work or not or have a line of cars waiting.

For example, I did a trip to a national park and they had 1 charging station location that was I think 45 minutes away to the national park. So I charged to 99%. When we got to the park, we had 76% left.

So we could drive around a little to sight see, but I was already planning that at 50%, we needed to leave regardless of what fun my we were having, since you don't want to drain below 20% and I wanted to keep the 20% as a safety buffer because there was a time I spent 10% battery driving from one charging location to the next because the chargers were broken or charged too slow.

If I were you and you don't have access to an ice, I'd calculate how much you'd spend renting a small ICE plus gas VS how much EV will cost you.

transport.comment:
GTELs or Gas turbine electric locomotives are from time to time built and employed usually targeted to specific applications where high power needs and / or reduced mass needs out weigh the fuel economy needs of the prime mover or generator unit of an electric traction locomotive.  In such specific cases it proves a better choice than the much more common diesel engine as prime unit generator for a electric traction locomotive.  The gas turbine provided the necessary high power electrical output required for the electric traction motors to very effectively pull large loads up steep grades.  The Union Pacific GTE Locomotives of the 60s where an example of this.   

A large reason for the poor fuel economy of GTELs is because they have typically operated on electric platforms that are just electric drive trains and no significant energy storage (batteries) to compliment the gas turbine as we find in vehicles with series hybrid and range extender designs.  The gas turbine had to throttle up and down to constantly meet the changing output / load needs.   In such an electric drive train with minimal energy storage designs, the diesel engine is generally a more economical fit and thus very common today as the power generator of choice for electric traction locomotives as well as large earth movers.  

But the game is very different in a BEV with ER, battery (electric vehicle with range extender).  Note: these are also known as an in series hybrid electric vehicle where the engine provides entirely or most of the long range needs and where the batteries handle the bulk of the average driving cycle.   

As a range extender for a BEV, a gas turbine is able to operate at its most efficient when ever called upon to provide the additional power.  A gas turbine excels in the hybrid electric environment because it is the one engine that can operate at full rpm / peak load without seeing self destruction that we see in the reciprocating and constant volume engines (rotary - Wankel included).  All other engines considered for range extension cannot operate long peak power or as mechanics would call it "their sweet spot".   And operating at their design point is very important when employed as a range extender because an engine that can do so will offer the most power per mass.  Indeed a gas turbine is healthiest when operating at its design point / peak power / "sweet spot".  Thus it can achieve an even higher value than its already high value of KW / KWG.  No other energy generator can touch this.  

 The gas turbine further returns the favor.  It allows the batteries to do what they do best and removes the problems of over heating, over charging (beyond 80 percent for LI ion), cold ambient effect on battery chemistry, under charging issues, battery safety concerns and etc.  Most importantly, the much lighter MGT (micro gas turbine) plus fuel tank replaces the much greater battery weight that would be required to meet that occasional long range need.  This extra battery weight is a weight penalty carried around for occasional need for most of the average driving cycle.  And it still does not get close to removing the range anxiety when driving in those charging deserts, that a GT range extender can achieve.  In fact a GT does not even need a gas station as they have been run on whiskey and perfume in a pinch.

Gas turbines are much more fuel flexible than their reciprocating intermittent combustion isometric counterparts.    And that brings me back to those GTE Locomotives.  One of the motivations for the Union Pacific creating its GTEL fleet was that those trains could run on bunker fuel which at the time was dirt cheap.  This was a substantial cost savings at least until the arrival of the mid seventies energy crisis which drove up the price of even a once  throwaway fuel.  

Today, this feature of gas turbines and especially when packaged with a BEV can very effectively run on carbon neutral fuels.  That combined with the low emissions at exhaust make for a very clean engine.  Cleaner by far than a non hybrid BEV when using the more accurate well to wheel analysis.  

Because of their relatively low pressure ratio, modern KW (or micro) gas turbines can also make use of heat recovery components (recuperators or regenerators) that dramatically improve a micro gas turbine's fuel economy.  Such add in components are relatively easy to do with adiabatic isobaric Brayton cycle engines but very difficult with the conventional isometric engines.  Such heat recovery components further improve an engine's fuel economy while reducing exhaust temperatures and dampening sound.  

This adding in (within the T cycle to enhance the T cycle) of components is not at all possible in the isometric engines (SI, - gasoline PI diesel and SI rotary).    It is a rare and valuable feature available to the GT engineer that allows them to literally alter the cycle to improve performance and efficiency.  For example - a gas turbine can be so altered as to convert it from a Brayton T cycle to an Ericson T cycle engine.  This type of advancement becomes even more possible when the GT is part of an electric power and drive train.  

Your BMW i3 would be well served with a small micro turbine range extender.  An already nice car made better with that swap from that little scooter engine to a small MGT that packs a lot more power for that range extender duty.  As I write this I am of the understanding that the BMW i3 is being discontinued.  How about bring it back with a TRE or turbine range extender.  That would be one hot little car.

housing.comment:
Expensive?  You know how cheap rail lines are, right?  Especially when bought in bulk?  They're basically extruded steel.

Highish maintenance?  It's a freaking motor, rail car, and rocks.  How is that high maintenance?

> pumped storage

So instead of having a motor per car, you need a waterproof pump and a waterproof turbine?

> centrifuge storage

Which has a friction-caused parasitic loss which is a function of time.   With ARES, you get the same power out, regardless of whether you take it out 30 seconds later, or 30 months later.

> compressed air storage

And if the vessels burst?  Also, not terribly scalable.  You want to expand peak capacity?  Have to get another high pressure tank.  With ARES, it's as simple as getting more boxes of rocks, and a storage rack somewhere up hill.

> battery storage 

Finite life cycle, and most have some form of energy decay.

housing.comment:
Yes, but you save in batteries.

Solar panels are cheaper than batteries today. Assuming over 250 Ah batteries and proper high quality deep cycle batteries.

They are all rated for 700-1200 discharges at 20% discharge rates. And general consensus is never to discharge them over %50.

This means you need a huge array of batteries if you only want to discharge 20% per day and have them working for 5-10 years.

The Nife Batteries, are from 400 Ah to 1000 Ah, and you can discharge them up to 80%. Even if you do 100% you don't actually kill them. You can't kill them. They seem to be rated for 10,000 cycles and then you can just replace the electrolyte fluid and again they are as new.

What you invest in more panels you save in batteries. Seems like a no brainier to me if you have the solar space. I tend to use more energy at night, so the storage part would be by far more important for me than energy production.

housing.comment:
Yea, I think it's totally fair to evaluate solar based solely on its financial merits.  So let's do the numbers:

Based on my 11 year break even point and a minimum 25 year lifespan, that gives me a ROI of around 122% for my 11 years of sunk capital.  To match that in the market would require about 8% compounding annually, over and above inflation.  That's certainly possible, but probably not in what I would consider "low risk" investments, whereas I consider solar very low risk.  Also, for all practical purposes energy is not an optional purchase.  You're going to buy electricity no matter what price it's at.  So If you make 10% in the stock market, but have to pay 11% higher energy costs, you've actually net lost money.  Solar is a hedge against that.

&#x200B;

The way I think of it, if the power company sent you a flyer tomorrow that said, "Prepay for 10 years of electricity and get an additional 15 years free", my guess is a lot of financially reasonable people would take that option.  But when you stamp the word "Solar" on that offer, people seem to hesitate.

Lastly, regulatory uncertainty is a fair point.  However, there have been some states that have amended or abolished net metering, and as far as I know, they have all grandfathered in existing customers.  Michigan's net metering law actually states that they only have to offer it for a maximum of 1% of retail customers.  Last I heard, Michigan is nowhere near 1% solar.

>..direct subsidies to Tesla for Powerwalls

That would be hard to break out because it's part of the product line that Tesla Inc. manufactures. To my knowledge, subsidies for individual products aren't broken out. It's a fair question if you also ask Tesla the same question.

>How big are the cost of building roads to support the auto..

If all you wanted to do was save as much money as possible you wouldn't be driving an EV in the first place.

For backup power, skip the batteries and install a whole house generator and transfer switch for 1/3 the cost and 2x the utility. You are also confused on NEM. It is only after your 12 month relevant period is over that the reimbursement rate for excess backfed energy is $0.03/kwhr This rate applies to NEM 1.0 customers as well.

housing.comment:
This will work so long as you have a Backup Gateway in your system that's correctly wired and configured. Here is an installation manual with wiring diagrams in back showing various ways that can be hooked up:

[https://www.tesla.com/sites/default/files/pdfs/powerwall/Powerwall\_2\_AC\_GW2\_NA\_EN\_Installation\_Manual.pdf](https://www.tesla.com/sites/default/files/pdfs/powerwall/Powerwall_2_AC_GW2_NA_EN_Installation_Manual.pdf)

I understand that the transfer time from on-grid to standalone operation is rather slow, though, compared to a typical UPS - some threads at [teslamotorsclub.com](https://teslamotorsclub.com) state 200-500ms, slow enough to crash most computers, so unfortunately you'd probably still need a small UPS on those. It may be good enough to not bother your HVAC system much during the transition, though some may shut down briefly to protect against compressor short-cycling.

Does anyone have a current, official transfer-time spec? Hopefully this is something they can improve via software updates? The huge 200A contactor in the Backup Gateway will impose a certain minimum time, but should still be capable of better than 200ms.

My Outback inverter will switch in about 32ms (2 60Hz cycles), more than a typical UPS but good enough to keep all the computers & electronics happy. Faster is possible if I were willing to waste \~20W 24/7 to keep the inverter on "hot standby", and its transformer relay always closed. It was nice to get rid of all those little desk-side units with their short-lived batteries.  The Outback's transfer relay is only 60A-rated, though, which helps for speed.

housing.comment:
While I can't tell you what to ultimately do, I will tell you what I an in the process of doing.  I am building a house right now and wanted to add solar.  Where I am in Wisconsin, being grid tied has no money making aspects ( poor net metering).  So instead of integrating to the grid and paying a transmission fee just for being connected (un-avoidable fee), we opted to just be off-grid with whole house battery. same store as you panel warranty are 25 years and battery warranty is considered 6000 cycles or so.  (Lithium deep cycle batteries).  This doesnt mean they are done after that warranted amount, but depending on how the parts are used they may or may not last much longer.  Lithium Batteries will last much long as long as the charge is never depleted below 80% depth of discharge (below 20% battery life remaining).  That wears a battery out much quicker.  So I plan on taking good care of my equipment to get the best life out of them.

Your AC situation is of course different than mine.  Batteries may need to be sizes larger which is much more costly.  My total off grid system cost was about $44,000.  Half of that was for the batteries.  I am installing this system myself.  Hope this helps. -Wisconsin

>Nobody is making an environmental argument based on market decisions

Here is the news for you: maybe we should already?

Although, no, subsidies and funding are pretty much interventions and tools to regulate the market, so we are actively making 'the market' to take such decisions and alter it. 

>The issue is economic. We're making an economic argument.

The issue is surely economic, but it's also economic as in not taking the said decisions and not further introducing anything possible would mean an economic mini-catastrophy at best, on top of everything.

And no, it's not just an economic argument. It's a policy decision issue, where somehow many are tying to stupid short-term profit-driven decisions of market across and the market fundamentalist arguments. 

>But if you wanna talk environmental issues and externalities

Surely, let's talk about making the bloody emissions and harms due to it, including the production and transfer, included into the price so that the market actors can sink to the bottom as they would need to pay the price if they are into polluting things or into enjoying things from the pollution havens. 

>nuclear takes big issues with it's 500k years of fuel storage problem

Okay, hear me out: I'd rather deal with the nuclear waste issue or downsides of the battery production and the solar panel production and hazardous solid waste that'll rise from it than furthering the global warming to the point of altering the climate change to an irreversible level, killing out tons of species, destroying the arable land and causing grave displacements, starvation, and chaos. 

>national security risk

Heck, energy dependency and dependency on gas and oil supplies is the very national security risk instead. Not to mention, tolerating climate change resulting in grave national security risks by itself. 

>and future possible uninhabitable metropolitan areas.

Again, I'd rather deal with the issues rising from hazardous solid waste from solar panels, storage of the nuclear waste, battery production related issues etc. than literally bringing on mini-catastrophies onto the said metropolitan areas, including climate refugees, resource wars, water scarcity, unbearable heat waves, and killing the nature on the side. 

>Trying to build nuclear in spite of the economics

Stupid neo-liberal paradigm and the comical kind of market fundamentalist economic models' failed axioms =/= economics. The very environmental economy and environmental movement, minus the eco-modernist kumbaya, is about going against the status quo and the existing market paradigm & production and consumption patterns.

housing.comment:
This is my answer too. This isn't 5 states being super responsible - this is 5 states not thinking things through fully. Banning ICE cars just hurts poor people in the short term. Banning gas for heating and cooking just hurts poor people. Subsidizing solar panels on rich people's roofs to create often-useless power is bad for poor people.

when is it?

**EDIT #2::**

I agree with the premise that they should break up. But for the opposite reason. Meat isn't an addiction, it's something he's _choosing_ to do. He did it, knowing how she felt about it, of his own free will and now is complaining that he has to suffer the consequences. If he feels that strongly about eating animals, then he a) needs to get rid of this "part time vegan" nonsense, clearly he doesn't have a problem with hurting animals if he just "indulges" guiltlessly every 60 days b) needs to find a relationship where he can either behave responsibly (i.e in accordance with the expectations that he's established with his girlfriend) or where she's a fellow omni. 

I also don't think he has the best of intentions at heart if he would be that cavalier about using "fuck her." Not that he needs to turn it into a Harlequin novel, but it does seem a pretty negative way to phrase it. 

Savage obviously went off in typical omni fashion, where your ethical choice is basically the same level as deciding to wear bright fuschia t-shirts the rest of your life. Just really really hateful, and over nothing more than being more compassionate than he is. He called it controlling, but we're dealing with ethics here, it's reasonable to assume at least our SO's will adhere to some fundamental tenet that we value. Would expecting your SO to not go through GTA-style mass killing be "controlling." >how come veg/vegans still get shit for wanting to help the planet, be healthier and save some animals? I just don't get it....

Because other people don't want to be veg/vegan and our very existence shows many self-proclaimed "animal lovers" that their exploitation and killing of animals is very unnecessary and hard to justify. 

>BUT the factory farming industry should be reason enough for human CONSCIOUSNESS to rise above our cravings for dead flesh/puss filled cow milk... right??

I'd think that animal farming period should be reason enough. I hope so. Otherwise people are just going to pay more for stupid crap like "free range" eggs that are still awful and unnecessary. 

>Anyone else get these damn comments about how god made animals for us to eat?

Yep, from my mom. And I've gotten worse from that, I assure you. Ironically, I've gotten some of the craziest shit from people I really try *not* to talk to about veganism (or at least in the situations that I'm around them for). I'm not one to back down from a good debate, but even I have my limits and I do have some sense. 

In any case, Facebook sucks. Seriously, when I was on it I started liking people I had friended less and less because there is crap you just don't want to know about people and vice versa (including them just acting dumb). I feel like I'm actually closer to people -- in a good way -- now that I'm off. If I have exciting stuff to share then I can pick up the phone and actually have a real conversation and there's more to talk about because not everyone has heard all the details of my life and vice versa.

food.comment:
You know, someone in this thread said that they might have been messing with you, and I have the same suspicion.

You say "where potatoes were a rare occurence". This is weird because people in countries with harsh winters tend to eat a lot of potatoes since you can store them in the basement throughout the entire winter. So if they didn't even have potatoes available...What did they eat?

That potato comment makes me think that it's either someone who's messing with you  or someone who's old enough to have gone through famine.

And to answer your question, I'm on a tight budget right now, so I eat a lot of rice +vegetables + cucumber or potatoes + vegetables + cucumbers, if I'd be in my cold home country right now,  I'd eat the same way, just with more soups and stews.

Of course, I tend to stay in the cities, it might be different in villages, though in my country you can get vegetables everywhere, so it's doable.

Also I'm pretty sure that although being 100% vegan might be difficult due to the limited food choices, being 100% vegetarian is probably much cheaper than being an omnivore, and from what I understand back in the day people in villages ate meat only on special occasions (because, you know, you had to actually slaughter a pig, and then pig was gone).

P.S. B12 might be an issue, so probably if someone can't get supplements, then some eggs and/or dairy here and there would be the way to go for our poor rural vegan.

P.P.S. Did that person tell you which exact region of Russia he was from?

I've been pretty happy with the cost savings I've had in adopting a vegan diet. My market does occasionally have good sales on meat and dairy but for the most part, that shit is just way too expensive for what you get. food.comment:
I love the Veganomicon cookbook.

For pasta, 
Bolognese: I either cook dried lentils with a bit of garlic and sweet potato, then add to my tomato pasta sauce, OR add in a can of lentils. 
Creamy tomato pasta: do a regular tomato based sauce, and add in either ground almonds (like the stuff you bake fancy flourless chocolate cakes with) or some kind of vegan cream cheese like tofutti.
Roasted pumpkin pasta: roast or pan fry onions and heaps of cubes of butternut pumpkin in lots of olive oil. Add to pasta with baby spinach and some olives or fresh tomatoes.

Hope these help! One thing I do to save time, I will cook up a whole bunch of lentils (whole red lentils) with garlic and sweet potato, then freeze them in meal size containers. Then it makes it way easier when I want to make a quick & filling pasta or curry. Lentils are really filling and cheap, especially if you have any Indian, Asian or bulk food grocery nearby.

food.comment:
Okay but I don't condone the breeding of animals for food, as I've stated already.
And killing an animal for food is not cruel. Theres a meaning to that. And an understanding of what you're doing depending on how. And if it is done in a way where you yourself have an understanding and appreciation for what's being done, and an understanding for what you're taking away and you do it in a way that causes as little suffering as possible, as other animals typically do, then you're not being cruel. Being cruel is willfully causing pain and suffering and having NO CONCERN about it. Again, language is deliberate. You can't just go aaaah this fits my view so I'm going to say it's cruel and just preach that to everyone, because that's not true. In fact, it is essentially a lie. And is extreme.

And science states that there are essential nutrients we need from animals that we literally cant get from anywhere else. So that's not a fact. Can we live without them? Yea. But were not perfectly healthy and at optimal levels without them. Now with that being said, we're really only.supposed to est like 4oz of meat with 1 meal like twice a week if you're trying to live as long as possible. And you can see this in the history of the way different regions live and eat and average life expectancy for those regions. 

Veganism has been taken to huge extremes recently that were never even apart of it before simply because it's a trend and now a bunch of you are uneducated and just spewing whatever bs you "feel is right" and you're spreading misinformation. But now it's all anyone can do to say don't eat honey because that's not vegan which is false. There's a lot of ways to be vegan. food.comment:
I don't think you can draw that conclusion. Here's why:

Changing someone's mind doesn't just happen in a handful of interactions. You can see going vegan as installing anti-carnist software. It requires hundreds of steps, thousands of seperate ideas. If you were to put all the necessary ideas in a single conversation it would literally be a day long. (The average audiobook of a 200-300 page intro to veganism book is something like 10-15 hours of monologue audio so two way is probably at least double that, and a full vegan worldview probably requires more than just 200-300 pages). Even merely recognising that *maybe* this is something you need to worry about takes a lot of updating your worldview already.

Activists generally have two approaches to get a person from A to B:

* Directly communicate a single step (works whether a person want to listen or not)

* Get a person intrinsically motivated to investigate the entire topic thoroughly

You and I will almost certainly agree the second option is ultimately the best because short of teaching a compulsory class on veganism this is the only way to actually get a person from A to B.

However the problem is for a topic to be investigated through intrinsic motivation you have to *know it exists* in the first place.

This teachers is great at the first method. I am sure close to all students will leave that school knowing that veganism exists and have a rough idea of what it is about. They'll have negative attitudes about it sure. But if someone with more tact comes along who also happens to be vegan these students'll now have some background knowledge and this second person may get them started on method 2.

In short I think true change requires us to 1) make noise, 2) make people investigate once we've got their attention. For both steps (in what is ultimately a gradual process) different levels of tact work best. Imo being a bit forward/abbrasive as often as possible gets as as many people as possible to the starting line of method two while reducing the likelihood of method 2 working. More passive approaches make metgod two more likely to work but reduce the number of people getting to the starting line of method 2.

So imo, if it weren't for the loud and out annoying vegans the more reasonable activists wouldn't have many people to work with.

Getting people to listen and getting them motivated to know more require opposing levels of tact.

Just my 2 cents on this endless debate.

food.comment:
Yes. But I was referring to a specific discourse from what you most commonly find now as "regenerative grazing fans". They have an entire [pseudoscience](https://tabledebates.org/publication/grazed-and-confused) relating to the environment, it's akin to flatearther pseudoscience.

One of their myths is that the soy grown in the world isn't mostly raised for animal feed. They do this by calling it a byproduct, a waste of making soybean oil. This isn't as much pseudoscience as it is disinformation, as the soybean meal and cakes are coproducts, not waste. But this is the kind of shit I have to deal with just on reddit.

Another myth is that herding/ranching doesn't impact the water cycle (consume extra water leading to no water) because cows urinate. 

Another myth, aside from the carbon storage one, is that grasses and trees are friends. No, really.

There are many myths. It's basically like trying to talk to a creationist about science.  

 And they have decent funding and make up lots of documentaries. Obviously, they're supported by [Big Meat](https://jacobinmag.com/2022/03/big-agriculture-funding-regenerative-ranching-amp-grazing-soil-carbon/) as they serve the role of a greenwashing front, but they also represent the settler-colonial "Beef Lebensraum" tradition. One of their heroes, [Savory, is such a piece of shit](https://web.archive.org/web/20210619043046/https://theecologist.org/2021/jun/14/regenerative-ranching-racket-0). 

https://www.rangemagazine.com/archives/stories/fall99/allan_savory.htm

https://freefromharm.org/agriculture-environment/saving-the-world-with-livestock-the-allan-savory-approach-examined/

https://newrepublic.com/article/163735/myth-regenerative-ranching



I have more links here: https://www.reddit.com/user/dumnezero/comments/ozqqey/from_cattle_to_capital_how_agriculture_bred/ and https://www.reddit.com/user/dumnezero/comments/q22d0w/why_scientists_believe_meat_has_dire_consequences/ 

(see comments on all)

The evil-stupid binary in this case is formed of evil capitalists and stupid fascists. The /r/carnivore crowd is also contributing to it.

https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/when-nazis-tried-bring-animals-back-extinction-180962739/


And, yes, the "red meat to white meat" transition is a known phenomenon, even in developed countries. On the other hand, the "beef only" crowd and industry try to make it look like that luxury is actually ESSENTIAL, as early as possible (they're trying to get parents to feed beef to babies). This also reflects that supremacism culture tied to pastoralist cultures, European and non-European, in which consuming red meat especially from "grass fed free range" and, if that fails, from CAFOs, is an essential part of the identity. 

Dairy distribution is somewhat limited by lactose intolerance and casein allergy. It's true that it's an important aspect, but the Diary sector is the Meat sector. 


> when reactionaries started screaming that leftists wanted to ban burgers, i knew that it was economics that will make beef prohibitively expensive for working class before anything else. 

To put it simply, the beef eating fascists want more for them, at whatever the costs to everyone else. Raising cows in any system is terrible (which is what the pseudosciences are for), but the very extensive system which they claim "ideal" is incompatible with reality. It has to lead to taking lands in order to convert them to pastures. This is obvious with the ongoing Amazon genocide where the ranchers are at the "frontier" of converting Amazonians' forests into beef. This is less obvious with the Sudan genocide going on now, as the RSF are part of herder mafias trying to, among other things, clear land (of people) in order [to raise cows to sell to the bourgeois classes](https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/ex-un-official-control-livestock-trade-with-the-gulf-to-halt-sudan-war) in the petrostates of the Middle East, especially the [UAE](https://suna-sd.net/posts/sudan-uae-to-strengthen-cooperation-in-livestock-sector).

In the literature, this one is called "the farmer herder conflict". There's lots to read. Example https://documents.sfcg.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Pastoralism_and_Conflict_in_the_Sudano-Sahel_Jul_2020.pdf

food.comment:
No, of course not, it would make people very angry. I did try to convince them to switch to non-meat foods for their animals (also dogs) but they didn't want to (it was a few years ago when I worked there). They even ridiculed it, which was a reason I quit. I don't want to work to help animals, while this organizations pays companies to abuse even more animals. Look, animals have to die regardless! And not just die, but some animals need to be killed and it's either the one cat or a lot of others. And those others will be created especially for the cat, and they will have bad lives.

I tried to talk to my dad about this, but yeah he isn't vegan and he reacted just like you guys are reacting now.
